Department of Agriculture and Technical Instruction for Ireland.
G.T.739
FOOD PRODUCTION SCHEMES, IRELAND, 1917
Memorandum prepared in compliance with Chief Secretary's Minute of 17th March, 1917
Week ending 16th May, 1917?
The following is a brief summary of the work of the Department during the past week in connection with the special Schemes for Increased Food Production in Ireland:-
The Administration of the : Regulation enforcing Compulsory Tillage
The number of cases to date in which the Department have entered, or have made arrangements to enter upon holdings for the purpose of having the requisite area placed under cultivation is 303.
Out of the 8,531 cases in which warning notices were served, 5,124 have now been reported as satisfactory,
Local organisation through Co. Committees of Agriculture
Weekly reports of the Agricultural Instructors express general satisfaction with the progress of tillage. Practically all the grain crops and potatoes have be on sown.
A special campaign has been initiate by the Department with a view to inducing the farmers to spray their potatoes this year, and to secure with-out delay supplies of spraying machines and materials for the purpose. Arrangements are being made in each county for the holding of a large number of public meetings in the evenings and on Sundays after Church services. Instructors and overseers are interviewing traders in their districts who deal' in spraying requisites to ensure that orders for spraying requisites will be placed at once. The local committees of farmers which have played such an important part in the Spring Tillage Campaign are being utilised to assist in this matter, and also in the matter of securing adequate supplies of harvest requisites and machinery. Loans for Agricultural Implements
Seventy-one ? applications for loans for agricultural implements were received by the Department during the past week. The total value ? ordered to date under the Scheme is 32,276.
Supply of Motor Tractors and Ploughs
There is nothing of special interest to report under this heading. The Department's Motor Tractors ? which were on hire throughout the country have now been practically all returned to store.
Transit of Farming-Requisites
The work of facilitating the conveyance of seeds from Northern Stations has now been completed. An officer continues to be engaged in Dublin on the special work of facilitating the transit of agricultural requisites.
During the week 4,600 tons of manures, 129 boxes of spraying machines and a number of binders and threshing machines, arrived at the Port of Dublin.
Particular attention is being given to the transit of basic slag sulphate of copper and spraying machines.
Labour troubles at the Port of Dublin have unfortunately interfered with sailings to and from the Port.
Maintenance of Live Stock
During the period from the 8th to the 14th inst., inclusive, 663 applications for licences to slaughter or export under the order relating to breeding sows were received, and 470 licences wore issued.
